results.title: Aussie Ashes win
results.brief_description: After crushing the Brits with a 4-0 sweep in the 2021 Ashes series, the Aussie team celebrated with the customary champagne popping. But not everyone could join in. Skipper Pat Cummins told the players to put down the bottles so Usman Khawaja, who is Muslim and doesn’t drink alcohol, could rejoin. Khawaja killed it in the fourth test, where he made a century in both innings he played. He tweeted the footage, heralding the moment as a step ‘in the right direction’ towards better inclusivity, acknowledging that there’s more work to be done to address racism in Australian sport.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

After crushing the Brits with a 4-0 sweep in the 2021 Ashes series, the Aussie team celebrated with the customary champagne popping. But not everyone could join in. Usman Khawaja was integral throughout the series, particularly in the fourth test when he made a century in both innings, but as a Muslim doesn’t drink alcohol. Skipper Pat Cummins told the players to put down the bottles so that he could rejoin the festivities. Khawaja retweeted the footage, heralding the moment as a step ‘in the right direction’ towards better inclusivity, subtly acknowledging that there’s more work to be done to address racism in Australian sport.

Read Osman Faruqi’s analysis of the moment on they Sydney Morning Herald.
description_for_label: After crushing the Brits with a 4-0 sweep in the 2021 Ashes series, the Aussie team celebrated with the customary champagne popping. But not everyone could join in. Usman Khawaja was integral throughout the series, particularly in the fourth test when he made a century in both innings, but as a Muslim doesn’t drink alcohol. Skipper Pat Cummins told the players to put down the bottles so that he could rejoin the festivities. Khawaja retweeted the footage, heralding the moment as a step ‘in the right direction’ towards better inclusivity, subtly acknowledging that there’s more work to be done to address racism in Australian sport.

results.title: Living with crocodiles
results.brief_description: Saltwater crocodiles are the largest reptiles in the world and one of the deadliest hunters - an amazing survival story from the age of the dinosaurs. Northern Australia is one of the last places on earth where large numbers flourish in close proximity to the human population, and in the Northern Territory a unique experiment is being carried out which could lead to long term conservation of this otherwise endangered species.

results.title: Spawn
results.brief_description:
What do freak-science, fairies and queer flower coding have in common?

These themes intersect in a new experimental video work by Te Whanganui A-Tara based artist Laura Duffy. “Spawn” explores political underpinnings of categorisations of ‘natural’ and ‘unnatural’ in relation to bodies. Exploring critically the process of bodies considered natural or normal.

“Spawn” is an ACMI + CIRCUIT Commission which supports an invited Australasian artist to deliver an experimental new work specifically for an online context.
results.description:
Spawn is a gift to those of us (so many of us!) who have been living through lockdowns. With the unwelcome mantle of ‘most locked-down city in the world’, Melbourne audiences were at the forefront of artist Laura Duffy’s mind when she created Spawn. Duffy mixes materials together like potions, encouraging audiences to consider texture through filmic spaces in which the natural and unnatural writhe upon one another – slipping, dripping, bubbling, congealing.

Responsive to a context of global pandemic mixed in with climate crisis, Duffy is moved by sentiments of kindness and generosity, inviting audiences into the ‘poetic, fun, fresh, flowery, camp and flirty’ world of Spawn.

The work reflects Duffy’s belief that materials are collaborative, complete with their own stories, histories and energies. The artist combines these materials to critique and shatter binary thinking of natural and unnatural as separate, instead embracing the complexity and blur of binaries. ‘How are we able to unleash from the constraints of “nature” to find new pleasures? A Post-nature embrace of all that is and will be, even if it’s toxic?’ Duffy questions.

Spawn is also a work about gratitude. A filmic study of death and transformation. As golden liquid pours over rotting, spinning fruits and flowers, Duffy encourages us to ‘say thank you and rejoice in transformation and transmutation.’

An additional element of the work will be released in January 2022. Conscious that so many of us have been confined to our homes and tied to our screens, Duffy is collaborating with artist and friend Aliyah Winter to create a downloadable audio work that we can walk around with, enjoying at our leisure, wherever we please.

– Serena Bentley, Curator, ACMI
description_for_label:
What do freak-science, fairies and queer flower coding have in common?

These themes intersect in a new experimental video work by Te Whanganui A-Tara based artist Laura Duffy. “Spawn” explores political underpinnings of categorisations of ‘natural’ and ‘unnatural’ in relation to bodies. Exploring critically the process of bodies considered natural or normal.

“Spawn” is an ACMI + CIRCUIT Commission which supports an invited Australasian artist to deliver an experimental new work specifically for an online context.

results.title: Analects of Kung Phu: Book 1, The 69 Dialogues between the Lamp and the Shadow
results.credit_line:
Jason Phu
Three-channel video installation, 85 mins.
Edited by Conor Bateman
Mordant Family Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection
results.brief_description: During times of uncertainty, people look for guidance. Jason Phu found it in martial arts films. By reclaiming wise sayings from movies and TV shows Analects of Kung Phu presents a moving image philosophy for surviving contemporary life.

constellations_primary.name: Jason Phu and genre-bending kung fu films
constellations_primary.description: Analects of Kung Phu work is a philosophical guide to life via martial arts films, drawing on his interest in Vietnamese and Chinese folklore, which inspires many of the films featured in this Constellation.

results.title_for_label: Analects of Kung Phu: Book 1, The 69 Dialogues between the Lamp and the Shadow
results.description:
“I want to create something that is genuinely useful but is also aware of its own representational fallacies and historical inaccuracies. I hope that people notice the highly personal nature of this work and feel inspired to make their own compendium of sayings to guide their own lives.” – Jason Phu

During times of uncertainty, people look for guidance. Jason Phu found it in martial arts films. By reclaiming wise sayings from movies and TV shows like Drunken Master (1978) and Avatar the Last Airbender (2005–08), Analects of Kung Phu presents a moving image philosophy for surviving contemporary life. Taught by action stars but inspired by classic Chinese texts like Lao Zi’s Dao De Jing, he questions whether these life lessons are genuinely useful. Phu is aware of how wisdom can be oversimplified and misused, how film subtitles miss the mark or even present a completely different narrative, and how we are guided in our day-to-day life by the movies we watch.

Leading Melbourne-based visual artist Jason Phu’s multi-disciplinary practice includes printmaking, installation, painting and video. Born in 1989 in Sydney, Australia, Phu lives and works in Melbourne, Australia. Phu’s artworks often explore Chinese histories in Australia, his own family history, and Chinese/Vietnamese folktales.

Jason Phu is the 2021 recipient of the Mordant Family Moving Image Commission for young Australian artists.

Read more

More than 200 kung fu films later, Jason Phu had his own movie to make by Kerrie O’Brien

My parents met at the fish market by Jason Phu in The Lifted Brow

Interview #34 — Jason Phu by Sophia Cai in Liminal

Storytelling with Jason Phu by Sabina McKenna in Acclaim

Who is Jason Phu? by Jane Albert in Broadsheet

results.title: [The funeral of Field Marshal Sir Thomas Blamey]
results.brief_description:
This film contains documentary footage of the state funeral of Field Marshal Sir Thomas Blamey, which took place on 30 May, 1951 in Melbourne, Victoria.

The film captures the funeral cortege as it proceeds along Swanston Street, with crowds of people lining the streets and buildings. The flag-covered casket is accompanied by a military band, soldiers and dignitaries. Significant public figures marching in the cortege include Prime Minister Robert Menzies, Governor-General William McKell, Governor of Victoria Sir Dallas Brooks and Chief Justice of the High Court Sir John Latham.

The film includes wonderful footage of Swanston Street from a high vantage point with the Shrine of Remembrance in the distance. There are also great shots of soldiers marching together, military horses, people gathered in front of the Melbourne City Baths and a couple watching on atop the facade of the ‘W.H. Terry Memorial Hall’.

An estimated 300,000 people turned out to watch the funeral procession, which travelled from the Shrine of Remembrance, along St Kilda Road, and up Swanston Street to College Crescent, before proceeding by car to Fawkner Crematorium.

Sir Thomas Blamey (24 Jan 1884 – 27 May 1951) was a General in the Australian army and the only Australian to have achieved the rank of Field Marshal.
